content.title: Inflation
content.definition: A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services in an economy over a period of time, resulting in a decrease in the purchasing power of money.

definitions_glossary.price_level: The average of current prices across the entire spectrum of goods and services in the economy
definitions_glossary.purchasing_power: The quantity of goods and services that can be purchased with a unit of currency
definitions_glossary.hyperinflation: Extremely rapid or out-of-control inflation, typically exceeding 50% per month
definitions_glossary.deflation: A sustained decrease in the general price level, the opposite of inflation
definitions_glossary.disinflation: A decrease in the rate of inflation (prices still rising, but more slowly)
definitions_glossary.stagflation: Simultaneous occurrence of stagnant economic growth, high unemployment, and high inflation
definitions_glossary.core_inflation: Inflation excluding volatile food and energy prices to reveal underlying trends
definitions_glossary.inflation_expectations: What consumers, businesses, and investors anticipate future inflation will be

key_points: Inflation erodes the purchasing power of money over time, meaning each unit of currency buys fewer goods and services
Measured primarily by Consumer Price Index (CPI) and Producer Price Index (PPI)
Moderate inflation (2-3% annually) is considered healthy for economic growth; very high or very low inflation creates problems
Three main causes: demand-pull (excess demand), cost-push (rising input costs), and built-in (wage-price spiral)
Central banks use monetary policy (interest rates, money supply) to target specific inflation rates
Inflation redistributes wealth from lenders to borrowers and from those with fixed incomes to those with flexible incomes
Anticipated inflation can be planned for; unexpected inflation creates economic uncertainty and inefficiency

examples.title: U.S. Inflation Example (2021-2023)
examples.description: U.S. inflation rate rose from 1.4% (2020) to 7.0% (2021) to 9.1% peak (June 2022), then declined to 3.4% (2023). A basket of goods costing $100 in 2020 cost $115.40 by end of 2023.
examples.context: Post-pandemic inflation driven by supply chain disruptions, fiscal stimulus, and pent-up demand

examples.title: Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe (2007-2009)
examples.description: Zimbabwe experienced hyperinflation reaching 79.6 billion percent per month in November 2008. Prices doubled every 24.7 hours. Eventually abandoned their currency for US dollars.
examples.context: Caused by excessive money printing to finance government deficits, loss of agricultural production, and economic mismanagement

examples.title: Demand-Pull Inflation Example
examples.description: During housing boom, increased demand for homes pushed prices up 20% annually in some markets. Banks expanded lending, buyers bid up prices, creating self-reinforcing cycle.
examples.context: Demonstrates how excess demand relative to supply drives prices higher

examples.title: Cost-Push Inflation Example
examples.description: 1970s oil shocks: OPEC quadrupled oil prices in 1973-74. Transportation, heating, and manufacturing costs rose sharply, pushing up prices across economy despite weak demand.
examples.context: Shows how rising input costs get passed through to consumers as higher prices

content.statement: Inflation is a sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services in an economy over time, reducing the purchasing power of money and affecting economic decisions of consumers, businesses, and policymakers.

explanation.intuition: Inflation means 'your money doesn't go as far as it used to.' If inflation is 3%, something that cost $100 last year costs $103 this year. Over time, this compounds - $100 in 2000 had the purchasing power of about $180 in 2024. Inflation isn't necessarily bad; moderate inflation encourages spending and investment rather than hoarding cash. But high inflation creates problems, and deflation (falling prices) can be even worse, as it encourages people to delay purchases.
explanation.key_insight: Inflation is fundamentally about the relationship between money supply and goods/services available. Too much money chasing too few goods drives prices up (demand-pull). Rising production costs force businesses to raise prices (cost-push). And inflation expectations become self-fulfilling: if workers expect 5% inflation, they demand 5% raises, businesses raise prices 5% to cover costs, validating the original expectation (wage-price spiral).
explanation.technical_details: Inflation rate = [(CPI_current - CPI_previous) / CPI_previous] × 100%. Fisher equation links nominal interest rate, real interest rate, and inflation: i = r + π, where i = nominal rate, r = real rate, π = inflation rate. Central banks target inflation rates (typically 2% in developed economies) using Taylor Rule: i_t = r* + π_t + 0.5(π_t - π*) + 0.5(y_t - y*), where r* = equilibrium real rate, π* = target inflation, y = output gap.

mathematical_formulation.fisher_equation: Nominal Interest Rate = Real Interest Rate + Expected Inflation
mathematical_formulation.quantity_theory: MV = PY, where M = money supply, V = velocity, P = price level, Y = real output
mathematical_formulation.inflation_tax: Revenue = ΔM/P = (ΔM/M) × (M/P), erosion of real money balances

causes.demand_pull: Aggregate demand exceeds aggregate supply at current prices. Causes: fiscal stimulus, credit expansion, export surge, consumer confidence
causes.cost_push: Rising production costs force businesses to raise prices. Causes: wage increases, commodity price shocks (oil, food), import price increases, tax increases
causes.built_in: Wage-price spiral where past inflation leads to expectations of future inflation. Workers demand raises to maintain purchasing power, firms raise prices to cover costs
causes.monetary: Excessive money supply growth relative to economic output. 'Inflation is always and everywhere a monetary phenomenon' - Milton Friedman

effects.redistributive: Hurts fixed-income recipients, creditors, savers. Benefits debtors, flexible-income earners, real asset owners
effects.uncertainty: Makes long-term planning difficult, reduces investment, creates inefficient resource allocation
effects.menu_costs: Costs of changing prices - printing new menus, catalogs, updating systems
effects.shoe_leather_costs: Time and effort to minimize cash holdings when inflation is high
effects.tax_distortions: Bracket creep pushes taxpayers into higher brackets without real income gains. Capital gains overstated in nominal terms

explanation.measurement: Primary measures: CPI (consumer basket), PPI (producer goods), PCE (personal consumption expenditures - Fed's preferred), GDP deflator (entire economy). Each has strengths and limitations - CPI overstates due to substitution bias and quality improvements
explanation.policy_responses: Central banks raise interest rates to cool demand and reduce money supply growth. Fiscal restraint reduces government spending and deficits. Supply-side policies increase productive capacity. Wage-price controls (rarely used, generally ineffective)
